summary.long: 2 Samuel is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: After Saul died and David returned from defeating the Amalekites, David stayed in Ziklag two days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day a man came from Saul’s camp. His clothes were torn, and he had dirt on his head. When he came to David, he immediately bowed down with his face touching the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where did you come from?” David asked him.
“I escaped from the camp of Israel,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“What happened?” David asked him. “Please tell me.”
The man answered, “The army fled from the battle, and many of the soldiers died. Saul and his son Jonathan are dead too.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How do you know Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?” David asked the young man who had brought him the news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young man answered, “I happened to be on Mount Gilboa. Saul was there leaning on his spear, and the chariots and horsemen were catching up with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he looked back and saw me, he called to me, and I said, ‘Yes?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“He asked me, ‘Who are you?’
“I said to him, ‘I’m an Amalekite.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “He said to me, ‘Please stand over me and kill me. I’m alive, but I’m suffering.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So I stood over him and killed him, since I knew he couldn’t survive after he had been wounded. And I took the crown that was on his head and the band that was on his arm and brought them here to you, sir.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David grabbed his own clothes and tore them in grief. All the men with him did the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They mourned, cried, and fasted until evening because Saul, his son Jonathan, Yahweh’s army, and the nation of Israel had been defeated in battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked the young man who had brought him the news, “Where are you from?”
And the young man answered, “I’m an Amalekite, the son of a foreign resident.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked, “Why weren’t you afraid to take it upon yourself to destroy Yahweh’s anointed king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David called one of his young men and told him, “Come here and attack him.” David’s young man executed him
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while David said, “You are responsible for spilling your own blood. You testified against yourself when you said, ‘I killed Yahweh’s anointed king.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David wrote this song of mourning for Saul and his son Jonathan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said,
    “Teach this kesheth to the people of Judah.”
        (It is recorded in the Book of Jashar.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Your glory, Israel, lies dead on your hills.
    See how the mighty have fallen!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Don’t tell the news in Gath.
    Don’t announce the victory in the streets of Ashkelon,
        or the daughters of the Philistines will be glad,
            and the daughters of godless men will celebrate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You mountains in Gilboa,
    may there be no dew or rain on you
        or on your slopes,
            because warriors’ shields were tarnished there.
                Saul’s shield was never rubbed with olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From the blood of those killed and the fat of the warriors,
    Jonathan’s bow did not turn away,
        nor did Saul’s sword return unused.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul and Jonathan were loved and well-liked while they were living.
    They were not separated even when they died.
        They were swifter than eagles and stronger than lions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Daughters of Israel, cry over Saul,
    who dressed you in decorated, red clothes,
        who put gold jewelry on your clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
See how the mighty have fallen in battle!
    On your hills Jonathan was killed!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I am heartbroken over you, my brother Jonathan.
    You were my great delight.
        Your love was more wonderful to me than the love of women.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
See how the mighty have fallen!
    See how the weapons of war have been destroyed!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After this, David asked Yahweh, “Should I go to one of the cities of Judah?”
“Go,” Yahweh answered him.
“Where should I go?” David asked.
“To Hebron,” Yahweh replied.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went there with his two wives, Ahinoam from Jezreel and Abigail (who had been Nabal’s wife) from Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took his men and their families with him, and they settled in the towns around Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the people of Judah came to Hebron and anointed David to be king over the tribe of Judah.
They told David, “The people of Jabesh Gilead were the ones who buried Saul.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent messengers to the people of Jabesh Gilead. He said to them, “May Yahweh bless you because you showed kindness to your master Saul by burying him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May Yahweh always show you kindness. I, too, will be good to you because you did this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, be strong and courageous. Because your master Saul is dead, the tribe of Judah has anointed me to be their king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ner’s son Abner, commander of Saul’s army, took Saul’s son Ishbosheth and brought him to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner made him king of Gilead, Asher, Jezreel, Ephraim, and Benjamin, that is, all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul’s son Ishbosheth was 40 years old when he became king of Israel. He ruled for two years, but the tribe of Judah followed David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Hebron David was king over the tribe of Judah for seven years and six months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ner’s son Abner and the officers of Saul’s son Ishbosheth went from Mahanaim to Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zeruiah’s son Joab and David’s officers also left Hebron. Both groups met at the pool of Gibeon. They sat down there, one group on one side of the pool and the other group on the other side of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner said to Joab, “Let’s have the young men hold a contest.” Joab agreed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men got up and were counted as they passed by. Twelve were from the tribe of Benjamin (representing Saul’s son Ishbosheth), and twelve were from David’s officers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one grabbed his opponent by the head, stuck his sword into his opponent’s side, and they fell down together. Therefore, that place in Gibeon is called the Field of Enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fierce fighting broke out that day, and David’s men defeated Abner and the men of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zeruiah’s three sons were there: Joab, Abishai, and Asahel. Asahel was as fast on his feet as a wild gazelle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He chased Abner and refused to leave him alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Abner looked back, he asked, “Are you Asahel?”
“Yes,” Asahel answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abner told him, “Leave me alone! Catch one of the young men, and take his weapon.”
But Asahel refused to turn away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner spoke again to Asahel. “Stop following me,” he said. “Why should I kill you? How could I look your brother Joab in the face again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Asahel refused to turn away. So Abner struck him with the butt of the spear. The spear went into his belly and came out his back. He fell down there and died on the spot. And everyone who came to the place where Asahel fell and died stopped there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab and Abishai chased Abner. When the sun went down, they came to the hill of Ammah, opposite Giah on the road from Gibeon to the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of Benjamin rallied behind Abner, banding together and taking their position on top of a hill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner called to Joab, “Should this slaughter go on forever? Don’t you know this will end in bitterness? How long will it be before you will call off your troops from chasing their relatives?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab answered, “I solemnly swear, as Elohim lives, if you had not spoken, the men would not have stopped chasing their relatives until morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab blew a ram’s horn, and all the troops stopped. They didn’t chase or fight Israel anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner and his men marched through the plains all that night. They crossed the Jordan River and passed through the entire Bithron until they came to Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab returned from chasing Abner. When he had gathered all the troops, only 19 of David’s officers and Asahel were missing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, David’s officers had killed 360 of the men of Benjamin under Abner’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Asahel and buried him in his father’s tomb in Bethlehem. Then Joab and his men marched all night and arrived at Hebron by daybreak.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the war between the royal families of Saul and David dragged on, David’s family became stronger and stronger, and Saul’s family became weaker and weaker.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sons were born to David while he was in Hebron. His first son was Amnon, born to Ahinoam from Jezreel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The second was Chileab, born to Abigail (who had been Nabal’s wife) from Carmel. The third was Absalom, whose mother was Maacah (the daughter of King Talmai) from Geshur.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fourth was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith. The fifth was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sixth was Ithream, born to David’s wife Eglah. These sons were born to David while he was in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the war between the families of Saul and David, Abner strengthened his position in Saul’s royal family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Saul had a concubine named Rizpah (Aiah’s daughter). Ishbosheth asked Abner, “Why did you have sex with my father’s concubine?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth’s question made Abner very angry. “Have I been behaving like some Judean dog?” he asked. “Until now I’ve been faithful to your father Saul’s family, to his relatives and friends, and I haven’t handed you over to David. But now you charge me with a crime because of this woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May Elohim strike me dead unless I do for David what Yahweh had promised him with an oath:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I, Yahweh, will transfer the kingship from Saul’s family and establish David’s throne over Israel and Judah from Dan to Beersheba.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ishbosheth couldn’t respond to a single word, because he was afraid of Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abner sent messengers to David to speak on his behalf. “Who owns this country?” he asked. “Make an agreement with me,” he said. “I’ll support you and bring all Israel to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Good!” David answered. “I’ll make an agreement with you. But there’s one condition: You can’t come to see me unless you bring Michal, Saul’s daughter, when you come.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent messengers to Saul’s son Ishbosheth to say, “Give me my wife Michal. I made a payment of 100 Philistine foreskins for her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ishbosheth sent men to take her from her husband Paltiel, son of Laish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her husband went with her and cried over her all the way to Bahurim. “Go home,” Abner told him. So he went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Abner sent the following message to the leaders of Israel: “For some time now you’ve wanted to make David your king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do it now, because Yahweh said about David: ‘I will save my people Israel from the Philistines and all their other enemies through my servant David.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abner also spoke specifically to the people of Benjamin.
Then Abner went directly to David in Hebron to tell him everything Israel and the entire tribe of Benjamin had approved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abner came with 20 men to David in Hebron, and David had a feast for Abner and his men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abner told David, “I must go now so that I can gather all Israel for you, Your Majesty. They will make a treaty with you, and you will rule everything your heart desires.” Then David dismissed Abner, who left peacefully.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then David’s men and Joab were coming home from a raid with a lot of goods. Abner had been dismissed, so he was no longer with David in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab came back with the whole army, he was told, “Ner’s son Abner came to the king, but David dismissed him, and Abner left peacefully.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab went to the king and asked, “What have you done? Abner came to see you. Why did you dismiss him and let him get away?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Certainly you must know that Ner’s son Abner came to deceive you, to find out about your movements and learn everything you’re doing!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After leaving David, Joab sent messengers after Abner. They brought him back from the cistern of Sirah without David knowing about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Abner returned to Hebron, Joab took him aside in the gateway as if to talk to him privately. There he stabbed Abner in the belly. Abner died because he spilled the blood of Joab’s brother Asahel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later when David heard about it, he said, “As far as Yahweh is concerned, my kingdom and I are forever innocent of spilling the blood of Ner’s son Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the blame fall on the head of Joab and all of his family. May there always be members of Joab’s family who have oozing sores and skin diseases, who can only work a spindle, who die in battle, and who never have any food.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Joab and his brother Abishai killed Abner because he had killed their brother Asahel in the battle at Gibeon.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told Joab and all the people with him, “Tear your clothes, put on sackcloth, and mourn for Abner.” King David followed the open casket.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried Abner in Hebron. The king cried loudly at Abner’s grave, and all the people cried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king sang a funeral song for Abner:
    Should Abner die like a godless fool?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Your hands were not tied.
    Your feet were not chained.
    You fell as one falls in front of wicked men.
And all the people continued to cry for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That entire day all the people tried to get David to eat some food. But David had taken an oath: “May Elohim strike me dead if I taste any food or anything else before the sun goes down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people understood and approved of this, as all the people approved of everything the king did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day all the people of Israel knew the king wasn’t responsible for killing Ner’s son Abner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to his officers, “Don’t you know that today a leader, a great man, has fallen in Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today I’m weak, though I’m the anointed king. These men, Zeruiah’s sons, are too cruel for me. May Yahweh repay this evildoer as his evil deeds deserve.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Saul’s son Ishbosheth heard that Abner had died in Hebron, he lost his courage, and all Israel was alarmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Saul’s son had two men who were captains of raiding parties. One was named Baanah, and the other was named Rechab. They were the sons of Rimmon from Beeroth from the tribe of Benjamin.
(Beeroth was considered a part of Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: even though the people of Beeroth had fled to Gittaim. They still live there today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, Saul’s son Jonathan had a son who was crippled. When the boy was five years old, the news about the death of Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel. His nurse picked him up and fled to Gittaim. She was in a hurry when she left, and he fell from her arms and became disabled. His name was Mephibosheth.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rechab and Baanah, the sons of Rimmon from Beeroth, came to Ishbosheth’s home at the hottest time of the day. Ishbosheth was taking his midday nap
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when they came into the house as though they were going to get some flour. Instead, they stabbed him in the belly. Then Rechab and his brother Baanah escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (They had come into the house while Ishbosheth was sleeping on his bed in his bedroom. They stabbed him, killed him, and cut off his head.) They took his head and traveled all night along the road to the plains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought Ishbosheth’s head to David at Hebron. “Here is the head of Ishbosheth, the son of your enemy Saul who tried to kill you,” they told the king. “Today Yahweh has given Your Royal Majesty revenge on Saul and his descendants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David responded to Rechab and his brother Baanah, the sons of Rimmon from Beeroth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I once seized a man who told me that Saul had died. He thought he was bringing good news. I killed him in Ziklag to reward him for his news.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How much more should I reward wicked men who kill an innocent man on his own bed in his home? Yahweh has rescued me from every trouble. I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, I’ll now seek revenge for his murder and rid the land of you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gave an order to his young men, who executed Rechab and Baanah, cut off their hands and feet, and hung their dead bodies by the pond in Hebron. Then they took Ishbosheth’s head and buried it in Abner’s tomb in Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the tribes of Israel came to David at Hebron. “We are your own flesh and blood,” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Even in the past when Saul ruled us, you were the one who led Israel in battle. Yahweh has said to you, ‘You will be shepherd of my people Israel, the leader of Israel.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the leaders of Israel had come to Hebron. King David made an agreement with them at Hebron in front of Yahweh. So they anointed David king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was 30 years old when he became king, and he ruled for 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Hebron he ruled Judah for seven years and six months. In Jerusalem he ruled for 33 years over all Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and his men went to Jerusalem to attack the Jebusites, who lived in that region. The Jebusites told David, “You will never get in here. Even the blind and the lame could turn you away” (meaning that David could never get in there).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But David captured the fortress Zion (that is, the City of David).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day David said, “Whoever wants to defeat the Jebusites must reach the lame and the blind who hate me by using the water shaft.” So there is a saying, “The blind and the lame will not get into the palace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David lived in the fortress and called it the City of David. He built the city of Jerusalem around it from the Millo to the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David continued to grow more powerful because Yahweh Elohim Tsebaoth was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedarwood, carpenters, and stonemasons. They built a palace for David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David realized that Yahweh had established him as king of Israel and made his kingship famous for the sake of Israel, Yahweh’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David married more concubines and wives from Jerusalem after he had come there from Hebron, and he fathered more sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of the children born to him in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ibhar, Elishua, Nepheg, Japhia,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king of Israel, all of them came to attack David. But David heard about it and went to the fortress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines had come and overrun the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked Yahweh, “Should I attack the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?”
Yahweh answered David, “Attack! I will certainly hand the Philistines over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David went to Baal Perazim and defeated the Philistines there. He said, “Yahweh has overwhelmed my enemies in front of me like an overwhelming flood.” That is why that place is called Baal Perazim [The Lord Overwhelms].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines left their idols there, so David and his men carried the idols away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines again attacked and overran the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked Yahweh, and he answered, “Don’t attack now, but circle around behind them, and come at them in front of the balsam trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear the sound of marching in the tops of the balsam trees, act immediately because Yahweh has gone ahead of you to defeat the Philistine army.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David did as Yahweh ordered him and defeated the Philistines from Geba to Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David again assembled all the best soldiers in Israel, 30,000 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He and all the people with him left Baalah in Judah to bring Elohim’s ark to Jerusalem. (The ark is called by the name of Yahweh Tsebaoth, who is enthroned over the angels.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and his men put Elohim’s ark on a new cart and brought it from Abinadab’s home on the hill. Uzzah and Ahio, Abinadab’s sons, were guiding the new cart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought it from Abinadab’s home, with Ahio walking ahead of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David and the entire nation of Israel were celebrating in Yahweh’s presence with all kinds of instruments made from cypress wood and with lyres, harps, tambourines, sistrums, and cymbals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they came to Nacon’s threshing floor, the oxen stumbled. So Uzzah reached out for the ark of Elohim and grabbed it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh became angry with Uzzah, so God killed him there for his lack of respect. He died beside the ark of Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was angry because Yahweh had struck Uzzah so violently. (That place is still called Perez Uzzah [The Striking of Uzzah] today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was afraid of Yahweh that day. “How can the ark of Yahweh come to my city?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David wouldn’t bring the ark of Yahweh with him to the City of David. Instead, he rerouted it to the home of Obed Edom, who was from Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ark of Yahweh stayed at the home of Obed Edom from Gath for three months, and Yahweh blessed Obed Edom and his whole family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David was told, “Yahweh has blessed Obed Edom’s home and everything he owns because of the ark of Elohim.” Then David joyfully went to get the ark of Elohim from Obed Edom’s house and bring it to the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When those who carried the ark of Yahweh had gone six steps, David sacrificed a bull and a fattened calf.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wearing a linen ephod, David danced in Yahweh’s presence with all his might.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He and the entire nation of Israel brought the ark of Yahweh with shouts of joy and the sounding of rams’ horns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the ark of Yahweh came to the City of David, Saul’s daughter Michal looked out of a window and saw King David leaping and dancing in Yahweh’s presence, so she despised him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men carrying the ark set it in its place inside the tent David had put up for it. David sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings in Yahweh’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had finished sacrificing the burnt offerings and the fellowship offerings, he blessed the people in the name of Yahweh Tsebaoth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also distributed to all the people—to the whole crowd of Israelites, both men and women—one loaf of bread, one date cake, and one raisin cake. Then all the people went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David returned to bless his family, Saul’s daughter Michal came out to meet him. “How dignified Israel’s king was today! He was exposing himself before the eyes of the slave girls of his palace staff—like a mindless fool might expose himself!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered Michal, “I didn’t dance in front of the slave girls but in front of Yahweh. He chose me rather than your father or anyone in your father’s house, and he appointed me leader of Israel, Yahweh’s people. I will celebrate in Yahweh’s presence,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I will degrade myself even more than this. Even if I am humiliated in your eyes, I will be honored by these slave girls you speak about.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Saul’s daughter Michal was childless her entire life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While King David was living in his house, Yahweh gave him peace with all his enemies around him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said to the prophet Nathan, “Look, I’m living in a house made of cedar, while the ark of Elohim remains in the tent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan told the king, “Do everything you have in mind, because Yahweh is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But that same night Yahweh spoke his word to Nathan:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say to my servant David, ‘This is what Yahweh says: Are you the one who will build me a house to live in?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I haven’t lived in a house from the day I took Israel out of Egypt to this day. Instead, I moved around in a tent, the tent of meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In all the places I’ve moved with all the Israelites, did I ever ask any of the judges of Israel whom I ordered to be shepherds of my people Israel why they didn’t build me a house of cedar?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now this is what you will say to my servant David: ‘This is what Yahweh Tsebaoth says: I took you from the pasture where you followed sheep so that you could be the leader of my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I was with you wherever you went, and I destroyed all your enemies in front of you. I will make your name famous like the names of the greatest people on earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make a place for my people Israel and plant them there. They will live in their own place and not be troubled anymore. The wicked will no longer oppress them as they used to do
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ever since I appointed judges to rule my people Israel. So I will give you peace with all your enemies. I, Yahweh, tell you that Yahweh will make a house for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “‘When the time comes for you to lie down in death with your ancestors, I will send one of your descendants, one who will come from you. I will establish his kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will build a house for my name, and I will establish the throne of his kingdom forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will be his Ab, and he will be my Son. If he sins, I will punish him with a rod and with blows inflicted by people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will never stop showing him my love as I did to Saul, whom I took out of your way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your royal house will remain in my presence forever. Your throne will be established forever.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan told David all these words and everything he had seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David went into the tent and sat in front of Yahweh. “Who am I, Adonay Yahweh,” he asked, “and why is my house so important that you have brought me this far?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And even this you consider to be a small act, Adonay Yahweh. You’ve also spoken about the distant future of my house. Adonay Yahweh, this is the teaching about the man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What more can I, David, say to you, Adonay Yahweh, since you know me so well!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’ve done this great thing because of your promise and your own desire. You made it known to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “That is why you are great, Adonay Yahweh. There is no one like you, and there is no other god except you, as we have heard with our own ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who is like your people Israel? It is the one nation on earth that Elohim came to free in order to make its people his own, to make his name known, and to do great and wonderful things for them. You forced nations and their gods out of the way of your people, whom you freed from Egypt to be your own.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You created the people of Israel to be your people forever. And you, Yahweh, became their Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, Yahweh Elohim, keep the promise you made to me and my house forever. Do as you promised.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your name will be respected forever when people say, ‘Yahweh Tsebaoth is Elohim over Israel.’ And the house of your servant David will be established in your presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, Yahweh Tsebaoth, Elohim of Israel, have revealed it especially to me, saying, ‘I will build a house for you.’ That is why I have found the courage to offer this prayer to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Adonay Yahweh, you are Elohim, and your words are trustworthy. You promised me this good thing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, please bless my house so that it may continue in your presence forever. Indeed, you, Adonay Yahweh, have promised it. With your blessing my house will be blessed forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, David defeated and crushed the Philistines. He took control of the main Philistine city from them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also defeated Moab, made the Moabites lie down on the ground, and measured them with a rope. He measured two lengths which were to be killed, and one length which was to be spared. So the Moabites became David’s subjects and paid taxes to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David went to restore his control over the territory along the Euphrates River, he defeated Zobah’s King Hadadezer, son of Rehob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took 1,700 horsemen and 20,000 foot soldiers from him. David also disabled all but 100 of their horses so that they couldn’t pull chariots.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans from Damascus came to help King Hadadezer of Zobah, David killed 22,000 of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David put troops in the Aramean kingdom of Damascus, and the Arameans became his subjects and paid taxes to him. Everywhere David went, Yahweh gave him victories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David took the gold shields that belonged to Hadadezer’s servants, and he brought them to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David also took a large quantity of bronze from Betah and Berothai, Hadadezer’s cities.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Toi of Hamath heard that David had defeated Hadadezer’s whole army,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he sent his son Joram to greet King David and congratulate him for fighting and defeating Hadadezer. (There had often been war between Hadadezer and Toi.) Joram brought articles of gold, silver, and bronze with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David dedicated these articles to Yahweh, along with the silver and gold he had dedicated from all the nations he conquered—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: from Edom, Moab, Ammon, the Philistines, Amalek, and from the goods taken from Zobah’s King Hadadezer, son of Rehob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David made a name for himself by killing 18,000 Edomites in the Dead Sea region as he returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put troops everywhere in Edom, and all the Edomites were David’s subjects. Everywhere David went, Yahweh gave him victories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David ruled all Israel. He did what was fair and right for all his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zeruiah’s son Joab was in charge of the army. Ahilud’s son Jehoshaphat was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahitub’s son Zadok and Abiathar’s son Ahimelech were priests. Seraiah was the royal scribe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada’s son Benaiah was commander of the Cherethites and the Pelethites. And David’s sons were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David asked, “Is there anyone left in Saul’s family to whom I can show kindness for Jonathan’s sake?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Now, Saul’s family had a servant whose name was Ziba. He was summoned to come to David. “Are you Ziba?” the king asked him.
“Yes, I am,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David asked, “Is there someone left in Saul’s family to whom I can show Elohim’s kindness?”
“Jonathan has a son who is disabled,” Ziba answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where is he?” the king asked.
Ziba replied, “He is at the home of Machir, Ammiel’s son, in Lo Debar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King David sent men to get him from the home of Ammiel’s son Machir in Lo Debar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Mephibosheth (son of Jonathan and grandson of Saul) came to David, he quickly bowed down with his face touching the ground.
“Mephibosheth!” David said to him.
“Yes, sir,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Don’t be afraid,” David told him, “I will certainly show you kindness for your father Jonathan’s sake. I will give back to you all the land of your grandfather Saul, and you will always eat at my table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth bowed down again and answered, “Who am I that you would look at a dead dog like me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king called for Ziba, Saul’s servant, and said to him, “I have given your master’s grandson everything that belonged to Saul and his family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You, your sons, and your servants should farm the land for him and harvest the crops so that your master’s family will have food to eat. However, your master’s grandson Mephibosheth will always eat at my table.” (Ziba had 15 sons and 20 servants.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ziba responded, “I will do everything you’ve commanded, Your Majesty.” From then on, Mephibosheth ate at David’s table as one of the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth had a young son whose name was Mica. Everyone who lived at Ziba’s home became Mephibosheth’s servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Mephibosheth, who was disabled, lived in Jerusalem. He always ate at the king’s table.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later the king of Ammon died, and his son Hanun became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David thought, “I will show kindness to Hanun as his father Nahash showed me kindness.” So David sent his servants to comfort Hanun after his father’s death. But when David’s servants entered Ammonite territory,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Ammonite princes asked their master Hanun, “Do you think David is honoring your father because he sent men to comfort you? Hasn’t David sent his men to explore the city, spy on it, and destroy it?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hanun took David’s men, shaved off half of each man’s beard, cut off their clothes from the waist down, and sent them away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David was told what had happened, he sent someone to meet them because they were deeply humiliated. The king said to them, “Stay in Jericho until your beards have grown back, and then return to Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites realized that they had made themselves offensive to David. So they hired the Arameans from Beth Rehob and Zobah (20,000 foot soldiers), the army of the king of Maacah (1,000 men), and the men of Tob (12,000 men).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David heard about this, he sent Joab and all the elite troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites formed a battle line at the entrance of the city gate, while the Arameans from Zobah and Rehob and the men from Tob and Maacah remained by themselves in the open country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Joab saw he was under attack in front and behind, he took the select troops of Israel and organized them for combat against the Arameans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put his brother Abishai in charge of the rest of the troops. Abishai organized them for combat against the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab said, “If the Arameans are too strong for my troops, be ready to help me. And if the Ammonites are too strong for your troops, I’ll come to help you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be strong! Let’s prove ourselves strong for our people and for the cities of our Elohim, and Yahweh will do what he considers right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab and his troops advanced to fight the Arameans, and the Arameans fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Ammonites saw that the Arameans had fled, the Ammonites fled from Abishai and went into the city. So Joab stopped his campaign against the Ammonites and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Realizing that Israel had defeated them, the Arameans reassembled their troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadadezer sent messengers to get Arameans from beyond the Euphrates River. The Arameans came to Helam with Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s army, leading them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was told about this, he assembled Israel’s army, crossed the Jordan River, and came to Helam. The Arameans formed a battle line against David’s troops and fought him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Arameans fled from Israel, and David killed 700 chariot drivers and 40,000 horsemen. David struck Shobach dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the kings who were subject to Hadadezer saw that Israel had defeated them, they made peace with Israel and became their subjects. And the Arameans were afraid to help the Ammonites anymore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring, the time when kings go out to battle, David sent Joab, his mercenaries, and Israel’s army to war. They destroyed the Ammonites and attacked Rabbah, while David stayed in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, when evening came, David got up from his bed and walked around on the roof of the royal palace. From the roof he saw a woman bathing, and she was very pretty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent someone to ask about the woman. The man said, “She’s Bathsheba, daughter of Eliam and wife of Uriah the Hittite.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David sent messengers and took her. She came to him, and he went to bed with her. (She had just cleansed herself after her monthly period.) Then she went home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman had become pregnant. So she sent someone to tell David that she was pregnant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David sent a messenger to Joab, saying, “Send me Uriah the Hittite.” So Joab sent Uriah to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah arrived, David asked him how Joab and the troops were and how the war was going.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go home,” David said to Uriah, “and wash your feet.” Uriah left the royal palace, and the king sent a present to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Uriah slept at the entrance of the royal palace among his superior’s mercenaries. He didn’t go home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they told David, “Uriah didn’t go home,” David asked Uriah, “Didn’t you just come from a journey? Why didn’t you go home?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uriah answered David, “The ark and the army of Israel and Judah are in temporary shelters, and my commander Joab and Your Majesty’s mercenaries are living in the field. Should I then go to my house to eat and drink and go to bed with my wife? I solemnly swear, as sure as you’re living, I won’t do this!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to Uriah, “Then stay here today, and tomorrow I’ll send you back.” So Uriah stayed in Jerusalem that day and the next.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David summoned him, ate and drank with him, and got him drunk. But that evening Uriah went to lie down on his bed among his superior’s mercenaries. He didn’t go home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the morning David wrote a letter to Joab and sent it with Uriah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the letter he wrote, “Put Uriah on the front line where the fighting is heaviest. Then abandon him so that he’ll be struck down and die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since Joab had kept the city under observation, he put Uriah at the place where he knew the experienced warriors were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city came out and fought Joab. Some of the people, namely, some of David’s mercenaries, fell and died—including Uriah the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab sent a messenger to report to David all the details of the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he commanded the messenger, “When you finish telling the king about the battle,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the king may become angry. He might ask you, ‘Why did you go so close to the city to fight? Didn’t you know they would shoot from the wall?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Who killed Jerubbesheth’s son Abimelech? Didn’t a woman on the wall of Thebez throw a small millstone at him and kill him? Why did you go so close to the wall?’ If the king asks this, then say, ‘Your man Uriah the Hittite is also dead.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger left, and when he arrived, he reported to David everything Joab told him to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger said, “Their men overpowered us and came to attack us in the field. Then we forced them back to the entrance of the city gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The archers on the wall shot down at your mercenaries, and some of Your Majesty’s mercenaries died. Your man Uriah the Hittite also is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David said to the messenger, “This is what you are to say to Joab, ‘Don’t let this thing trouble you, because a sword can kill one person as easily as another. Strengthen your attack against the city, and destroy it.’ Say this to encourage him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Uriah’s wife heard that her husband Uriah was dead, she mourned for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When her mourning was over, David sent for her and brought her to his home, and she became his wife. Then she gave birth to a son. But Yahweh considered David’s actions evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh sent Nathan to David. Nathan came to him and said, “There were two men in a certain city. One was rich, and the other was poor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich man had a very large number of sheep and cows,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the poor man had only one little female lamb that he had bought. He raised her, and she grew up in his home with his children. She would eat his food and drink from his cup. She rested in his arms and was like a daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Now, a visitor came to the rich man. The rich man thought it would be a pity to take one of his own sheep or cattle to prepare a meal for the traveler. So he took the poor man’s lamb and prepared her for the traveler.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David burned with anger against the man. “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives,” he said to Nathan, “the man who did this certainly deserves to die!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he must pay back four times the price of the lamb because he did this and had no pity.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are the man!” Nathan told David. “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: I anointed you king over Israel and rescued you from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I gave you your master Saul’s house and his wives. I gave you the house of Israel and Judah. And if this weren’t enough, I would have given you even more.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why did you despise my word by doing what I considered evil? You had Uriah the Hittite killed in battle. You took his wife as your wife. You used the Ammonites to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So warfare will never leave your house because you despised me and took the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be your wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what Yahweh says: I will stir up trouble against you within your own household, and before your own eyes I will take your wives and give them to someone close to you. He will go to bed with your wives in broad daylight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You did this secretly, but I will make this happen in broad daylight in front of all Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then David said to Nathan, “I have sinned against Yahweh.”
Nathan replied, “Yahweh has taken away your sin; you will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But since you have shown total contempt for Yahweh by this affair, the son that is born to you must die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Nathan went home.
Yahweh struck the child that Uriah’s wife had given birth to for David so that the child became sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David pleaded with Elohim for the child; he fasted and lay on the ground all night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The older leaders in his palace stood beside him to raise him up from the ground, but he was unwilling. And he wouldn’t eat with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day the child died. But David’s officials were afraid to tell him that the child was dead. They thought, “While the child was alive, we talked to him, and he wouldn’t listen to us. How can we tell him the child is dead? He may harm himself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But when David saw that his officials were whispering to one another, he realized that the child was dead. “Is the child dead?” David asked them.
“Yes, he is dead,” they answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David got up from the ground, bathed, anointed himself, and changed his clothes. He went into Yahweh’s house and worshiped. Then he went home and asked for food. They placed food in front of him, and he ate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officials asked him, “Why are you acting this way? You fasted and cried over the child when he was alive. But as soon as the child died, you got up and ate.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David answered, “As long as the child was alive, I fasted and cried. I thought, ‘Who knows? Yahweh may be gracious to me and let the child live.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But why should I fast now that he’s dead? Can I bring him back? Someday I’ll go to him, but he won’t come back to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David comforted his wife Bathsheba. He went to bed with her, and she later gave birth to a son. David named him Solomon. Yahweh loved the child
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and sent a message through the prophet Nathan to name the baby Jedidiah [The Lord’s Beloved].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Joab fought against the Ammonite city of Rabbah and captured its royal fortress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he sent messengers to tell David, “I fought against Rabbah and captured the fortress guarding its water supply.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gather the rest of the troops, surround the city, and capture it. Otherwise, I will capture the city, and it will be named after me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David gathered all the troops and went to Rabbah. He fought against the city and captured it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the gold crown from the head of Rabbah’s king and put it on his own head. (The crown weighed 75 pounds and contained a precious stone.) David also took a lot of goods from the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought out the troops who were there and put them to work with saws, hoes, and axes. He did the same to all the Ammonite cities. Then David and all the troops returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, David’s son Amnon fell in love with Tamar, the beautiful sister of David’s son Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon was so obsessed with his half sister Tamar that he made himself sick. It seemed impossible for him to be alone with her because she was a virgin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amnon had a friend by the name of Jonadab, a son of David’s brother Shimea. Jonadab was a very clever man.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He asked Amnon, “Why are you, the king’s son, so worn out morning after morning? Won’t you tell me?”
“I’m in love with Absalom’s sister Tamar,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab told him, “Lie down on your bed. Act sick, and when your father comes to see you, say to him, ‘Please let my sister Tamar come to feed me. She can prepare a meal in front of me as I watch her, and she can feed me.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Amnon lay down and acted sick, and the king came to see him. Amnon asked the king, “Please let my sister Tamar come and make some bread in front of me, and she can feed me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sent for Tamar at the palace. “Please go to your brother Amnon’s home,” he said, “and prepare some food for him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Tamar went to her brother Amnon’s home. He was lying down. She took dough, kneaded it, made flat bread in front of him, and cooked it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then she took the pan and served him the bread. But he refused to eat.
“Have everyone leave me,” he said. So everyone left him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amnon told Tamar, “Bring the food into the bedroom so that you can feed me.”
Tamar took the bread she had prepared and brought it to her brother Amnon in the bedroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she handed it to him to eat, he grabbed her and said, “Come to bed with me, Tamar!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No,” she told him, “don’t rape me! That shouldn’t be done in Israel. Don’t do this godless act!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Where could I go in my disgrace? And you will be considered one of the godless fools in Israel! Speak to the king. He won’t refuse your request to marry me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amnon wouldn’t listen to her. He grabbed his sister and raped her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Amnon developed an intense hatred for her. His hatred for her was greater than the lust he had felt for her. “Get out of here,” he told her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to him, “No, sending me away is a greater wrong than the other thing you did to me!” But he wouldn’t listen to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he called his personal servant and said, “Get rid of her. Put her out, and bolt the door behind her.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (She was wearing a long-sleeved gown. The king’s virgin daughters wore this kind of robe.) So his servant took her out and bolted the door behind her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tamar put ashes on her head, tore the long-sleeved gown she had on, put her hands on her head, and went away crying.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Her brother Absalom asked her, “Has your brother Amnon been with you? Sister, be quiet for now. He’s your brother. Don’t dwell on this matter.” So Tamar stayed there at the home of her brother Absalom and was depressed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David heard about this, he became very angry. But David didn’t punish his son Amnon. He favored Amnon because he was his firstborn son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom wouldn’t speak at all to Amnon. He hated Amnon for raping his sister Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two years later Absalom had sheepshearers at Baal Hazor near Ephraim. He invited all the king’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom went to the king and said, “Since I have sheepshearers, Your Majesty and your officials are invited to feast with me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “No, Son,” the king answered Absalom. “If we all go, we’ll be a burden to you.” Even when Absalom continued to urge him, David did not want to go, though he did give Absalom his blessing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Absalom said, “If you won’t go, then please let my brother Amnon go with us.”
“Why should he go with you?” the king asked him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Absalom urged him, he let Amnon and all the rest of the king’s sons go with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom gave an order to his servants. “Watch now,” he said. “When Amnon begins to feel good from drinking too much wine, I’ll tell you, ‘Attack Amnon.’ Then kill him. Don’t be afraid. I’ve given you the order, haven’t I? Be strong and courageous.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom’s servants did to Amnon as Absalom had ordered. Then all the king’s sons got up, mounted their mules, and fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were on their way, David heard this rumor: “Absalom has killed all the king’s sons, and not a single one is left.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king stood up, tore his clothes, and lay down on the ground. All his servants were standing beside him with their clothes torn to show their grief.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab, the son of David’s brother Shimea, said, “Sir, don’t think that all the young men, all the king’s sons, have been killed. Only Amnon is dead. Absalom decided to do this the day his half brother raped his sister Tamar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shouldn’t burden your heart with the idea that all the king’s sons are dead, Your Majesty. Only Amnon is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom has fled.”
When the servant who kept watch looked up, he saw many people coming down the road beside the mountain west of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jonadab told the king, “The king’s sons have come. It’s just as I said.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he finished speaking, the king’s sons arrived and cried loudly. The king and all his men also cried very bitterly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom, however, fled to Geshur’s King Talmai, Ammihud’s son. But the king mourned for his son Amnon every day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom, having fled to Geshur, stayed there three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David began to long for Absalom once people had consoled him over Amnon’s death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab, Zeruiah’s son, knew the king was still thinking about Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab sent someone to Tekoa to get a clever woman from there. He told her, “Please act like a mourner, and dress in mourning clothes. Don’t rub olive oil on yourself, but act like a woman who has been mourning for the dead for a long time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to the king, and tell him this. . . .” Then Joab told her exactly what to say.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman from Tekoa came to the king and immediately bowed down with her face touching the ground. “Help me, Your Majesty,” she said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king asked her, “What can I do for you?”
She answered, “I’m a widow; my husband is dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I had two sons who quarreled in the field, and there was no one to separate them. One killed the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the entire family turned against me. They said, ‘Give us the man who killed his brother so that we can kill him because he took his brother’s life. We’re going to destroy the one who now would be the heir.’ In this way they wish to extinguish the one burning coal that is left for me. They will not let my husband’s name or descendants remain on the face of the earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go home,” the king told the woman. “I will order someone to take care of this matter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman from Tekoa said to the king, “Let me be held responsible for the sin, Your Majesty. Let my father’s family be held responsible. Your Majesty and your throne are innocent.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “If anyone says anything against you, bring him to me. He’ll never harm you again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said, “Your Majesty, please pray to Yahweh your Elohim in order to keep an avenger from doing more harm by destroying my son.”
“I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives,” he said, “not a hair on your son’s head will fall to the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The woman said, “Please let me say something else to you.”
“Speak,” he said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Why have you devised something like this against Elohim’s people?” she said. “When you say this, you condemn yourself because you haven’t brought back the one you banished!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are all going to die; we are all like water that is poured on the ground and can’t be gathered up. But doesn’t Elohim forgive a person? He never plans to keep a banished person in exile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’ve come to say this to you because the people have frightened me. So I thought, ‘I will speak to the king about this. Maybe the king will do something for me, his subject.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Maybe the king will listen and rescue me, his subject, from the man who wants to cut off both me and my son from our Elohim-given inheritance.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I thought that you would reassure me. You are like Elohim’s Messenger, who is able to distinguish right from wrong. May Yahweh your Elohim be with you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king said to the woman, “Please don’t refuse to answer the question I’m going to ask you.”
The woman responded, “Please speak, Your Majesty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Did Joab put you up to this?” the king asked.
The woman answered, “I solemnly swear on your life, Your Majesty, you are absolutely right. Yes, your servant Joab ordered me to do this. He told me to say exactly what I said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your servant Joab has done this to portray the matter in a different light. You are as wise as Elohim’s Messenger, who knows everything on earth.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king told Joab, “This is what you’ll do. Bring back the young man Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab quickly bowed down with his face touching the ground, and he blessed the king. He said, “Today I know that you have been kind to me because you have done what I wanted.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab went to Geshur and brought Absalom back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “Absalom should return to his own house. He will not see me.” So Absalom returned to his house and didn’t see the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, no one in all Israel was praised for his good looks as much as Absalom was. He had no blemish from head to toe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of every year, he used to cut his hair because it became heavy for him. When he cut the hair on his head and weighed it, it weighed five pounds according to the royal standard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom had three sons and one daughter. His daughter Tamar was a beautiful woman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom stayed in Jerusalem two full years without seeing the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Absalom sent for Joab in order to send him to the king, but Joab refused to come. Absalom sent for him a second time, but he still refused to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Absalom said to his servants, “Look, Joab’s field is next to mine. He has barley in it. Go and set it on fire.” So Absalom’s servants set it on fire.
Joab’s servants came to him in grief and said, “Absalom’s servants have set your field on fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab immediately went to Absalom at his home. “Why did your servants set my field on fire?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom answered Joab, “I sent someone to tell you to come here because I wanted to send you to the king to ask him why I had to come from Geshur. It would be better for me if I were still there. Let me see the king now! If I’m guilty of a sin, he should kill me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab went to the king and told him this. The king then called for Absalom, who came to the king and bowed down with his face touching the ground. And the king kissed Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Soon after this, Absalom acquired a chariot, horses, and 50 men to run ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom used to get up early and stand by the road leading to the city gate. When anyone had a case to be tried by King David, Absalom would ask, “Which city are you from?”
After the person had told him which tribe in Israel he was from,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom would say, “Your case is good and proper, but the king hasn’t appointed anyone to hear it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He would add, “I wish someone would make me judge in the land. Then anyone who had a case to be tried could come to me, and I would make sure that he got justice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When anyone approached him and bowed down, Absalom would reach out, take hold of him, and kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what he did for all Israelites who came to the king to have him try their case. So Absalom stole the hearts of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Four years later Absalom said to the king, “Let me go to Hebron and keep the vow I made to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I made a vow while I was living at Geshur in Aram. I said, ‘If Yahweh will bring me back to Jerusalem, I will serve Yahweh.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Go in peace,” the king told him.
So he went to Hebron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Absalom sent his loyal supporters to all the tribes of Israel and said, “When you hear the sound of the ram’s horn, say, ‘Absalom has become king in Hebron.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Two hundred men invited from Jerusalem went with Absalom. They went innocently, knowing nothing about Absalom’s plans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Absalom was offering sacrifices, he sent for Ahithophel, David’s adviser, to come from his home in Giloh. Meanwhile, the conspiracy grew stronger, and the number of people siding with Absalom kept getting larger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Someone came to tell David, “The hearts of the people of Israel are with Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told all his men who were with him in Jerusalem, “Let’s flee immediately, or none of us will escape from Absalom. Let’s leave right away, or he’ll catch up to us and bring disaster on us when he massacres the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king’s servants told him, “No matter what happens, we are Your Majesty’s servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king left on foot, and his whole household followed him except ten concubines whom the king left behind to take care of the palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the king and his troops were leaving the city on foot, they stopped at the last house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All his mercenaries passed by him; all the Cherethites, all the Pelethites, Ittai, and all 600 men who had followed him from Gath were marching past the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked Ittai from Gath, “Why should you go with us? Go back, and stay with King Absalom. You are a foreigner, an exile from your homeland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You came to us just yesterday. Should I make you wander around with me when I don’t even know where I’m going? Go back, and take your countrymen with you. May the Lord always show you kindness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Ittai answered the king, “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh and the king live: Wherever you are, whether you’re dead or alive, I’ll be there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So David told Ittai, “Go ahead and keep marching.” So Ittai from Gath marched on with all his men and all the families who were with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole country was crying loudly as all the troops were passing by. The king was crossing the Kidron Valley, and all the people were moving down the road toward the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok and all the Levites with him were carrying the ark of Elohim’s promise. They set down the ark of Elohim beside Abiathar until all the troops had withdrawn from the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told Zadok, “Take Elohim’s ark back to the city. If Yahweh looks favorably on me, he will allow me to come back and see both it and its dwelling place again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if he says, ‘I’m not pleased with you,’ let him do to me what he considers right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Aren’t you a seer?” the king asked Zadok the priest. “Go back to the city peacefully, and take your son Ahimaaz and Abiathar’s son Jonathan with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll wait at the river crossings in the desert until I receive a message from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok and Abiathar took the ark of Elohim back to Jerusalem and stayed there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David cried as he went up the Mount of Olives. He covered his head and walked barefoot. And all of the troops with him covered their heads and cried as they went.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then David was told, “Ahithophel is among those conspiring with Absalom.” So David prayed, “Yahweh, make Ahithophel’s advice foolish.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to the top of the Mount of Olives where people worshiped Elohim, Hushai from Archi’s family was there to meet him. His clothes were torn, and he had dirt on his head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told him, “If you go with me, you will only be a burden to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you go back to the city and say to Absalom, ‘Your Majesty, I’ll be your servant. I was your father’s servant in the past, but now I’ll be your servant,’ then you’ll help me by undoing Ahithophel’s advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests Zadok and Abiathar will be with you there. When you hear anything from the royal palace, tell it to the priests Zadok and Abiathar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They have two sons with them: Zadok has Ahimaaz, and Abiathar has Jonathan. Send them to report to me anything you hear.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hushai, David’s friend, went to the city as Absalom was entering Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David had gone over the top of the Mount of Olives, Ziba, Mephibosheth’s servant, met him with a pair of saddled donkeys. They were loaded with 200 loaves of bread, 100 bunches of raisins, 100 pieces of ripened fruit, and a full wineskin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why did you bring these?” David asked Ziba.
“The donkeys are for the king’s family to ride on,” Ziba answered. “The bread and the ripe fruit are for your servants to eat. The wine is for those who become tired and thirsty in the desert.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Where is your master Saul’s grandson?” the king asked.
“He’s staying in Jerusalem,” Ziba answered the king. “He said, ‘Today the house of Israel will give me back my grandfather’s kingdom.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king told Ziba, “In that case everything that belonged to Mephibosheth now belongs to you.”
“I sincerely thank you,” said Ziba. “I hope to remain in your good graces, Your Majesty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King David came to Bahurim, a man who was a distant cousin of Saul came out cursing. His name was Shimei, son of Gera.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He threw stones at David and David’s servants, although all the people and all the warriors were shielding David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei cursed and said, “Get out! Get out, you bloodthirsty man! You worthless person!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh is paying you back for all the blood you spilled in the family of Saul, whom you succeeded as king. Yahweh is giving the kingship to your son Absalom. Now you’re in trouble because you’re a bloodthirsty man.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, asked the king, “Why should this dead dog curse you, Your Majesty? Let me go over there and tear off his head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king said, “You don’t think like me at all, sons of Zeruiah. Let him curse. If Yahweh has told him, ‘Curse David,’ should anyone ask, ‘Why do you do that?’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David told Abishai and all his servants, “My own son, my own flesh and blood, is trying to kill me. Why, then, shouldn’t this Benjaminite do this? Leave him alone. Let him curse, since Yahweh has told him to do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Maybe Yahweh will see my misery and turn his curse into a blessing for me today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As David and his men went along the road, Shimei was walking along the hillside parallel to him. Shimei cursed, hurled stones, and threw dirt at David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and all the people with him finally arrived at their destination and rested there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Absalom and all Israel’s troops came to Jerusalem, and Ahithophel was with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David’s friend Hushai from Archi’s family came to Absalom, he said, “Long live the king! Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Is that how loyal you are to your friend?” Absalom asked Hushai. “Why didn’t you go with him?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hushai answered Absalom, “No, I want to be with the one whom Yahweh, these people, and all Israel have chosen. I will be his friend and stay with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And besides, whom should I serve? Shouldn’t it be his son? As I served your father, so I’ll serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Absalom asked Ahithophel, “What’s your advice? What should we do?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel told Absalom, “Sleep with your father’s concubines whom he left to take care of the palace. Then all Israel will hear about how you have made your father despise you. Everyone who is with you will support you even more.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So a tent was put up on the roof for Absalom, and he slept with his father’s concubines in plain sight of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days both David and Absalom thought that Ahithophel’s advice was like getting an answer from Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahithophel said to Absalom, “Let me choose 12,000 men and leave tonight to go after David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll attack him while he’s tired and weak, and I’ll cause him to panic. All the people with him will flee, but I’ll kill only him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll return all the people to you as a bride is returned to her husband. Since you will be seeking the life of only one man, all the people will have peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and all the leaders of Israel approved this plan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom said, “Please call Hushai, who is descended from Archi’s family, and let us hear what he, too, has to say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hushai arrived, Absalom said to him, “Ahithophel has told us his plan. Should we do what he says? If not, tell us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This time Ahithophel’s advice is no good,” Hushai said to Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You know your father and his men. They are warriors as fierce as a wild bear whose cubs have been stolen. Your father is an experienced soldier. He will not camp with the troops tonight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has already hidden in one of the ravines or some other place. If some of our soldiers are killed in the initial attack, others will definitely hear about it and say, ‘The troops that support Absalom have been defeated.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the bravest man with a heart like a lion would lose his courage, because all Israel knows that your father is a warrior and the men with him are brave.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So my advice is to gather all Israel’s troops from Dan to Beersheba, since they are as numerous as the sand on the seashore. Lead them into battle yourself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then we’ll attack him wherever we find him. We’ll fall on him as dew falls on the ground. Neither he nor any of his men will be left alive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he retreats into a city, all Israel will bring ropes to that city and drag it into a valley so that not even a pebble will be found there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom and all the people of Israel said, “The advice of Hushai from Archi’s family is better than Ahithophel’s advice.” (Yahweh had commanded Ahithophel’s good advice to be defeated in order to ruin Absalom.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hushai told the priests Zadok and Abiathar, “Ahithophel advised Absalom and the leaders of Israel to do one thing, but I advised them to do something else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now send messengers quickly to tell David, ‘Don’t rest tonight in the river crossings in the desert, but make sure you cross the river, or Your Majesty and all the troops with him will be wiped out.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jonathan and Ahimaaz were waiting at En Rogel. They could not risk being seen coming into the city, so a servant girl was to go and tell them, and they were to go and tell King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a young man saw Jonathan and Ahimaaz and told Absalom. So both of them left quickly and came to the home of a man in Bahurim who had a cistern in his courtyard, and they went down into it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The man’s wife took a cover, spread it over the top of the cistern, and scattered some grain over it so that no one could tell it was there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Absalom’s servants came to the woman at her home. “Where are Ahimaaz and Jonathan?” they asked.
The woman said, “They’ve crossed the stream.”
The servants looked for them but did not find them. So Absalom’s servants returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Absalom’s servants left, both men came out of the cistern and went and told King David. “Leave right away,” they told David. “Cross the river quickly because this is what Ahithophel has advised against you. . . .”
verses.speaker: Narrator
