verses.text: David and all the troops with him left to cross the Jordan River. When the dawn came, everyone had crossed the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahithophel saw that his advice hadn’t been followed, he saddled his donkey, left, and went home to his own city. He gave instructions to his family. Then he hanged himself, died, and was buried in his father’s tomb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David had already come to Mahanaim by the time Absalom and all the men of Israel with him crossed the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom appointed Amasa to take Joab’s place as commander of the army. (Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra, a descendant of Ishmael. His mother was Abigail, the daughter of Nahash and sister of Joab’s mother Zeruiah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites and Absalom camped in the region of Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to Mahanaim, Shobi, son of Nahash from Rabbah in Ammon, and Machir, son of Ammiel from Lo Debar, and Barzillai from Rogelim in Gilead
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: brought supplies and food for David and his troops: bedding, bowls, pots, wheat, barley, flour, roasted grain, beans, lentils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: honey, buttermilk, sheep, and calves. They brought these things because they thought, “The troops in the desert are hungry, exhausted, and thirsty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David called together the troops that were with him. He appointed commanders in charge of regiments and battalions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
David put a third of the troops under Joab’s command, another third under Joab’s brother Abishai (Zeruiah’s son), and the last third under Ittai from Gath.
“I am going into battle with you,” the king said to the troops.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You’re not going with us,” the troops said. “If we flee, they won’t care about us, and if half of us die, they won’t care either. But you’re worth 10,000 of us. It’s better for you to be ready to send us help from the city.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’ll do what you think best,” the king responded. So the king stood by the gate while all the troops marched out by battalions and regiments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king ordered Joab, Abishai, and Ittai, “Treat the young man Absalom gently for my sake.” All the troops heard him give all the commanders this order regarding Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the troops went out to the country to fight Israel in the forest of Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There David’s men defeated Israel’s army, and the massacre was sizable that day—20,000 men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fighting spread over the whole country. That day the woods devoured more people than the battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Absalom happened to come face to face with some of David’s men. He was riding on a mule, and the mule went under the tangled branches of a large tree. Absalom’s head became caught in the tree. So he was left hanging in midair when the mule that was under him ran away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A man who saw this told Joab, “I saw Absalom hanging in a tree.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “What! You saw that!” Joab said to the man who told him. “Why didn’t you strike him to the ground? Then I would have felt obligated to give you four ounces of silver and a belt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the man told Joab, “Even if I felt the weight of 25 pounds of silver in my hand, I wouldn’t raise my hand against the king’s son. We heard the order the king gave you, Abishai, and Ittai: ‘Protect the young man Absalom for my sake.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If I had done something treacherous to him, would you have stood by me? Like everything else, it wouldn’t stay hidden from the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said, “I shouldn’t waste time with you like this.” He took three sharp sticks and plunged them into Absalom’s heart while he was still alive in the tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then ten of Joab’s armorbearers surrounded Absalom, attacked him, and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab blew the ram’s horn to stop their fighting, and the troops returned from pursuing Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They took Absalom, threw him into a huge pit in the forest, and piled a large heap of stones over him. Meanwhile, all Israel fled and went back to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (While he was still living, Absalom had taken a rock and set it up for himself in the king’s valley. He said, “I have no son to keep the memory of my name alive.” He called the rock by his name, and it is still called Absalom’s Monument today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz, Zadok’s son, said, “Let me run and bring the king the good news that Yahweh has freed him from his enemies.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Joab told him, “You won’t be the man carrying good news today. You can carry the news some other day. You must not deliver the news today because the king’s son is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab said to a man from Sudan, “Go, tell the king what you saw.” The messenger bowed down with his face touching the ground in front of Joab and then ran off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahimaaz, Zadok’s son, spoke to Joab again, “Whatever may happen, I also want to run after the Sudanese messenger.”
“Now, son, why should you deliver the message?” Joab asked. “You won’t be rewarded for this news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Whatever happens, I’d like to run,” replied Ahimaaz.
“Run,” Joab told him. So Ahimaaz ran along the valley road and got ahead of the Sudanese messenger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was sitting between the two gates while the watchman walked along the roof of the gate by the wall. As he looked, he saw a man running alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchman called and alerted the king.
“If he’s alone,” the king said, “he has good news to tell.” The runner continued to come closer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the watchman saw another man running, the watchman called, “There’s another man running alone.”
The king said, “This one is also bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The watchman said, “It seems to me that the first one runs like Ahimaaz, Zadok’s son.”
“He’s a good man,” the king said. “He must be coming with good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahimaaz came up to the king, greeted him, and bowed down in front of him. Ahimaaz said, “May Yahweh your Elohim be praised. He has handed over the men who rebelled against Your Majesty.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is the young man Absalom alright?” the king asked.
Ahimaaz answered, “I saw a lot of confusion when Joab sent me away, but I didn’t know what it meant.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Step aside, and stand here,” the king said. He stepped aside and stood there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Sudanese messenger came. “Good news for Your Majesty!” he said. “Today Yahweh has freed you from all who turned against you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Is the young man Absalom alright?” the king asked.
The Sudanese messenger answered, “May your enemies and all who turned against you be like that young man!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was shaken by the news. He went to the room above the gate and cried. “My son Absalom!” he said as he went. “My son, my son Absalom! I wish I had died in your place! Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab was told, “The king is crying and mourning for Absalom.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The victory of that day was turned into mourning because all the troops heard that the king was grieving for his son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day the troops sneaked into the city as if they had fled from battle and were ashamed of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king covered his face and cried loudly, “My son Absalom! Absalom, my son, my son!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joab came into the house. “Today you have made all your men feel ashamed,” he said. “They saved your life and the lives of your sons, daughters, wives, and concubines today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You love those who hate you and hate those who love you. Today, you have made it clear that your commanders and servants mean nothing to you. I think you would be pleased if Absalom were alive and all of us were dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, get up, go out, and encourage your men. I swear to you by Yahweh that if you don’t go out, no one will stay with you tonight, and that will be worse than all the trouble you’ve had in your entire life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king sat in the gateway. When all the troops were told, “The king is sitting in the gateway,” they came to the king.
Meanwhile, Israel had fled and went back to their own homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people in all the tribes of Israel were arguing with one another, saying, “The king rescued us from our enemies and saved us from the Philistines, but now he has fled from Absalom and left the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Absalom, whom we anointed to rule us, has died in battle. Why is no one talking about bringing back the king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: What all Israel was saying reached the king at his house. So King David sent this message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: “Ask the leaders of Judah, ‘Why should you be the last tribe to bring the king back to his palace?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are my relatives, my own flesh and blood. Why should you be the last to bring back the king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And tell Amasa, ‘Aren’t you my flesh and blood? May Elohim strike me dead unless you are given Joab’s place to serve me always as the commander of the army.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah were in total agreement. So they sent the king this message: “Come back with all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king came back to the Jordan River, and the people of Judah came to Gilgal to meet the king and bring him across the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei, Gera’s son from the tribe of Benjamin and the town of Bahurim, hurried down with the people of Judah to meet King David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One thousand people from Benjamin were with him. And Ziba, the servant of Saul’s family, rushed to the Jordan River across from the king. Ziba brought his 15 sons and 20 servants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They crossed the river to bring over the king’s family and to do anything else the king wanted.
Shimei, Gera’s son, bowed down in front of the king as he was going to cross the Jordan River.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He pleaded with the king, “Don’t remember the crime I committed the day you left Jerusalem. Don’t hold it against me or even think about it, Your Majesty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I know I’ve sinned. Today I’ve come as the first of all the house of Joseph to meet you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, replied, “Shouldn’t Shimei be put to death for cursing Yahweh’s anointed king?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David responded, “Are you sure we’re from the same family, sons of Zeruiah? You are my enemies today. Should anyone in Israel be killed today? Don’t I know that I’m king of Israel again?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king promised Shimei, “You won’t die,” and the king swore to it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mephibosheth, Saul’s grandson, went to meet the king. He had not tended to his feet, trimmed his mustache, or washed his clothes from the day the king left until he came home safely.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him, “Why didn’t you go with me, Mephibosheth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He answered, “My servant deceived me, Your Majesty. Since I am disabled, I said, ‘Saddle the donkey for me, and I’ll ride on it and go with the king.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told you lies about me, Your Majesty. However, you are like Elohim’s Messenger. Do what you think is right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You could have killed anyone in my entire family, Your Majesty. Instead, you’ve seated me with those who eat at your table. So I no longer have the right to complain to the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked him, “Why do you keep talking about it? I’ve said that you and Ziba should divide the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Let him take it all,” Mephibosheth told the king. “It’s enough for me that you’ve come home safely.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai, the man from Gilead, came from Rogelim with the king to the Jordan River to send him on his way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai was an elderly man, 80 years old. Because he was a very rich man, he had provided the king with food while he was staying at Mahanaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told Barzillai, “Cross the river with me. I’ll provide for you in Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Barzillai replied, “I don’t have much longer to live. I shouldn’t go with Your Majesty to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’m 80 years old now. How can I tell what is pleasant and what is not? Can I taste what I eat or drink? Can I still hear the singing of men and women? Why should I now become a burden to you, Your Majesty?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ll just cross the Jordan River with you. Why should you give me such a reward?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Please let me go back so that I can die in my city near the grave of my father and mother. But here is Chimham. Let him go across with you. And do for him what you think is right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Chimham will go across with me,” the king said. “I will do for him whatever you want. Anything you wish I’ll do for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the troops crossed the Jordan River, and then the king crossed. The king kissed Barzillai and blessed him. Then Barzillai went back home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king crossed the river to Gilgal, and Chimham went with him. All the troops from Judah and half of the troops from Israel brought the king across.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people of Israel kept coming to the king. They asked, “Why did our cousins, the people of Judah, kidnap you and bring Your Majesty and your family and men across the Jordan River?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah answered the people of Israel, “Because the king is our relative. Why are you angry about this? Did we eat the king’s food, or did he give us any gifts?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The people of Israel answered the people of Judah, “We have ten times your interest in the king and a greater claim on David than you have. Why, then, do you despise us? Weren’t we the first to suggest bringing back our king?”
But the people of Judah spoke even more harshly than the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A good-for-nothing man by the name of Sheba, Bichri’s son, from the tribe of Benjamin happened to be at Gilgal. He blew a ram’s horn to announce,
“We have no share in David’s kingdom.
We won’t receive an inheritance from Jesse’s son.
    Everyone to his own tent, Israel!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So all the people of Israel left David to follow Sheba, Bichri’s son. But the people of Judah remained loyal to their king on his way from the Jordan River to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David came to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines he had left to look after the palace and put them in a house under guard. He provided for them but no longer slept with them. So they lived like widows in confinement until they died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king told Amasa, “Call the people of Judah together for me, and in three days be here yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa went to call Judah together, but he took longer to do it than David had given him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David then told Abishai, “Sheba, son of Bichri, will do us more harm than Absalom. Take my men and go after him, or he will find some fortified cities and take the best ones for himself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joab’s men, the Cherethites, Pelethites, and all the soldiers went with Abishai. They left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, Bichri’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they were at the large rock in Gibeon, Amasa met them there. Joab wore a military uniform, and strapped over it at his hip was a sword in a scabbard. As he stepped forward, the sword dropped into his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “How are you, my brother?” Joab asked Amasa. He took hold of Amasa’s beard with his right hand to kiss him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa wasn’t on his guard against the sword in Joab’s left hand. Joab stabbed him in the stomach, and his intestines poured out on the ground. (He died without being stabbed again.) Then Joab and his brother Abishai pursued Sheba, son of Bichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One of Joab’s young men stood beside Amasa and said, “Anyone who favors Joab and is on David’s side should follow Joab.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amasa was wallowing in his blood in the middle of the road. When the man saw that all the troops stopped as they came to the body, he carried Amasa from the road to the field and threw a sheet over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he was moved from the road, everyone followed Joab and pursued Sheba, Bichri’s son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel to Abel (Beth Maacah). All the Berites were gathered together and followed him to the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab’s army came and attacked him in Abel (Beth Maacah). They put up a dirt ramp against the city, and it stood level with the outer wall. All the troops with Joab were trying to destroy the wall and tear it down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a clever woman called from the city, “Listen, listen! Tell Joab to come here so that I can talk to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He came near, and she asked, “Are you Joab?”
“I am,” he answered.
“Listen to what I have to say,” she told him.
“I’m listening,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she said, “There’s an old saying: ‘Be sure to ask at Abel before doing anything. That’s the way they settle matters.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We are peaceful and faithful Israelites. Are you trying to destroy a mother city in Israel? Why should you swallow up what belongs to Yahweh?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab answered, “That’s unthinkable! I don’t wish to swallow it up or destroy it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That isn’t the case. A man from the mountains of Ephraim by the name of Sheba, son of Bichri, has rebelled against King David. Give him to me, and I’ll withdraw from the city.”
“That’s fine,” the woman told Joab. “His head will be thrown to you from the wall.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the woman went to all the people with her clever plan. They cut off Sheba’s head and threw it to Joab. He blew the ram’s horn, and everyone scattered and withdrew from the city and went home. Joab went back to the king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Joab was put in charge of Israel’s whole army. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in charge of the Cherethites and Pelethites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoram was in charge of forced labor. Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the royal historian.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sheva was the royal scribe. Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And Ira, a descendant of Jair, was a priest to David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the time of David, there was a famine for three successive years, and David asked Yahweh’s advice about it. Yahweh answered, “It’s because of Saul and his family. They are guilty of murder because they killed the people of Gibeon.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
(The Gibeonites were not a part of Israel but were left over from the Amorites. Although the Israelites had sworn to spare them, Saul, in his eagerness, tried to destroy them for Israel and Judah.)
The king called the Gibeonites
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and asked them, “What can I do for you? What should I give you to make peace with you so that you will bless what belongs to Yahweh?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“We do not want silver or gold from Saul’s family,” the Gibeonites answered him. “And none of us wants to kill anyone in Israel.”
The king asked, “What are you saying that I should do for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They answered the king, “Give us seven of the male descendants of the man who wanted to finish us off. He planned to wipe us out to keep us from staying anywhere in Israel’s territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
We will execute them in Yahweh’s presence at Saul’s town Gibeah.” (It was Saul whom Yahweh had chosen.)
“I will give them to you,” the king said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king spared Mephibosheth, Jonathan’s son and Saul’s grandson, because of the oath in Yahweh’s name between David and Jonathan, son of Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king took Armoni and Mephibosheth, the two sons whom Rizpah (Aiah’s daughter) gave birth to for Saul, and five sons whom Merab (Saul’s daughter) gave birth to for Adriel, son of Barzillai from Meholah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king handed them over to the Gibeonites, who executed them on the mountain in Yahweh’s presence. All seven died together. They were killed at the beginning of the harvest, when people started harvesting barley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rizpah (Aiah’s daughter) took sackcloth and stretched it out on the rock for herself from the beginning of the harvest until the sky rained on the dead bodies. She wouldn’t let any birds land on them during the day or any wild animals come near them during the night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David was told what Saul’s concubine Rizpah (Aiah’s daughter) had done,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went and took the bones of Saul and of his son Jonathan from the citizens of Jabesh Gilead. They had stolen them from the public square of Beth Shean, where the Philistines had hung them the day they killed Saul at Gilboa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David brought up the bones of Saul and Jonathan, his men gathered the bones of those who had been executed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they buried the bones of Saul and his son Jonathan in the land of Benjamin, in Zela, in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish. They did everything the king ordered. After that, Elohim answered the prayers for the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Once again there was a battle between the Philistines and Israel. So David and his men went to fight the Philistines, but David became exhausted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A descendant of Haraphah named Benob, who had a bronze spear weighing 7½ pounds which he wore on a new belt, captured David and intended to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abishai, son of Zeruiah, came to help David. He attacked the Philistine and killed him. Then David’s men swore an oath, saying, “You’ll never go into battle with us again. The lamp of Israel must never be extinguished.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob. Then Sibbecai from Hushah killed Saph, another descendant of Haraphah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When more fighting broke out with the Philistines at Gob, Elhanan, son of Jaare Oregim from Bethlehem, killed Goliath of Gath. (The shaft of Goliath’s spear was like a beam used by weavers.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In another battle at Gath, there was a tall man who had a total of 24 fingers and toes: six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot. He also was a descendant of Haraphah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he challenged Israel, Jonathan, son of David’s brother Shimei, killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These four were descendants of Haraphah from Gath, and David and his men killed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David sang this song to Yahweh when Yahweh rescued him from all his enemies, especially from Saul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said,
Yahweh is my rock and my Metsuda and my Savior,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
my Elohim, my rock in whom I take refuge, my Magen,
    the strength of my salvation, my stronghold,
        my refuge, and my Savior who saved me from violence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh should be praised.
    I called on him, and I was saved from my enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The waves of death had surrounded me.
    The torrents of destruction had overwhelmed me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The ropes of the grave had surrounded me.
    The clutches of death had confronted me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I called on Yahweh in my distress.
    I called to my Elohim for help.
        He heard my voice from his temple,
            and my cry for help reached his ears.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the earth shook and quaked.
    Even the foundations of the heavens trembled.
        They shook violently because he was angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Smoke went up from his nostrils,
    and a raging fire came out of his mouth.
        Glowing coals flared up from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He spread apart the heavens
    and came down with a dark cloud under his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rode on one of the angels as he flew,
    and he soared on the wings of the wind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He surrounded himself with darkness.
    He made the dark rain clouds his covering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Out of the brightness in front of him, he made lightning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh thundered from heaven.
The Elyon made his voice heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He shot arrows and scattered them.
He flashed streaks of lightning and threw them into confusion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the ocean floor could be seen.
    The foundations of the earth were laid bare
        at Yahweh’s stern warning,
        at the blast of the breath from his nostrils.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He reached down from high above and took hold of me.
He pulled me out of the raging water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He rescued me from my strong enemy
    and from those who hated me,
        because they were too strong for me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On the day when I faced disaster, they confronted me,
    but Yahweh became my defense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He brought me out to a wide-open place.
    He rescued me because he was pleased with me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh rewarded me
    because of my righteousness,
    because my hands are clean.
He paid me back
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because I have kept the ways of Yahweh
    and I have not wickedly turned away from my Elohim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
because all his judgments are in front of me
    and I have not turned away from his laws.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I was innocent as far as he was concerned.
    I have kept myself from guilt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh paid me back
    because of my righteousness,
    because he can see that I am clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In dealing with faithful people you are faithful,
    with innocent warriors you are innocent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
with pure people you are pure.
In dealing with devious people you are clever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You save humble people,
    but your eyes bring down arrogant people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
O Yahweh, you are my lamp.
    Yahweh turns my darkness into light.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
With you I can attack a line of soldiers.
    With my Elohim I can break through barricades.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elohim’s way is perfect!
    The promise of Yahweh has proven to be true.
        He is a Magen to all those who take refuge in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Who is Elohim but Yahweh?
    Who is a rock other than our Elohim?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
El arms me with strength.
His perfect way sets me free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He makes my feet like those of a deer
    and gives me sure footing on high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He trains my hands for battle
    so that my arms can bend an archer’s bow of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have given me the shield of your salvation.
Your help makes me great.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You make a wide path for me to walk on
    so that my feet do not slip.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I chased my enemies and destroyed them.
I did not return until I had ended their lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I ended their lives by shattering them.
    They were unable to get up.
    They fell under my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You armed me with strength for battle.
You made my opponents bow at my feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You made my enemies turn their backs to me,
    and I destroyed those who hated me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They looked, but there was no one to save them.
They looked to Yahweh, but he did not answer them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I beat them into a powder as fine as the dust on the ground.
    I crushed them and stomped on them like the dirt on the streets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You rescued me from my conflicts with my people.
You kept me as the leader of nations.
    A people I did not know will serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners will cringe in front of me.
    As soon as they hear of me, they will obey me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Foreigners will lose heart,
    although they are armed in their fortifications.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh lives!
    Thanks be to my rock!
        May Elohim, the rock of my salvation, be glorified.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
El gives me vengeance!
    He brings people under my authority.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He frees me from my enemies.
    You lift me up above my opponents.
        You rescue me from violent people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I will give thanks to you, O Yahweh, among the nations
    and make music to praise your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He gives great victories to his king.
He shows mercy to his anointed,
    to David, and to his descendant forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These are the last words of David:
“Here is the declaration by David, son of Jesse—
the declaration by the man whom El raised up,
    whom the Elohim of Jacob anointed,
        the singer of Israel’s psalms:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Ruach Yahweh spoke through me.
His words were on my tongue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Elohim of Israel spoke to them.
The rock of Israel told me,
    ‘The one who rules humans with justice rules with the fear of Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He is like the morning light as the sun rises,
    like a morning without clouds,
        like the brightness after a rainstorm.
            The rain makes the grass grow from the earth.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Truly, El considers my house to be that way,
    because he has made a lasting promise to me,
        with every detail arranged and assured.
    He promised everything that helps me,
        everything that pleases me.
Truly, he makes these things happen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Worthless people are like thorns.
    All of them are thrown away, because they cannot be picked by hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
A person who touches them uses iron tools
    or the shaft of a spear.
    Fire will burn them up completely wherever they are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the names of David’s fighting men: Josheb Basshebeth from Tahkemon’s family was leader of the three. He used a spear to kill 800 men on one occasion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in rank to him was Eleazar, another one of the three fighting men. He was the son of Dodo and grandson of Aho. Eleazar was with David at Pas Dammim when the Philistines gathered there for battle. When the soldiers from Israel retreated,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he attacked and killed Philistines until his hand got tired and stuck to his sword. So Yahweh won an impressive victory that day. The army returned to Eleazar, but they only returned to strip the dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next in rank to him was Shammah, the son of Agee from Harar. The Philistines had gathered at Lehi, where there was a field of ripe lentils. When the troops fled from the Philistines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he stood in the middle of the field and defended it by killing Philistines. So Yahweh won an impressive victory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At harvest time three of the thirty leading men came to David at the cave of Adullam when a troop from the Philistine army was camping in the valley of Rephaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While David was in the fortified camp, Philistine troops were at Bethlehem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David became thirsty, he said, “I wish I could have a drink of water from the well at the city gate of Bethlehem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the three fighting men burst into the Philistine camp and drew water from the well. They brought it to David, but he refused to drink it. He poured it out as an offering to Yahweh and said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“It’s unthinkable that I would do this, Yahweh. This is the blood of men who risked their lives!” So he refused to drink it.
These are the things which the three fighting men did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab’s brother Abishai, Zeruiah’s son, was the leader of the thirty. He used his spear to kill 300 men. He was as famous as the three
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and was honored more than they were. So he became their captain, but he didn’t become a member of the three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was from Kabzeel and was a brave man who did many things. He killed two distinguished soldiers from Moab. He also went into a pit and killed a lion on the day it snowed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And he killed a handsome Egyptian. The Egyptian had a spear in his hand. Benaiah went to him with a club, grabbed the spear from him, and killed him with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the things that Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, did. He was as famous as the three fighting men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was honored more than the thirty, but he was not a member of the three. David put him in charge of his bodyguards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
One of the thirty was Joab’s brother Asahel. The thirty leading men were
Elhanan (son of Dodo) from Bethlehem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Shammah from Harod,
Elika from Harod,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Helez the Paltite,
Ira (son of Ikkesh) from Tekoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abiezer from Anathoth,
Mebunnai (son of Hushai),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zalmon (descendant of Ahohi),
Maharai from Netophah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Heleb (son of Baanah) from Netophah,
Ittai (son of Ribai) from Gibeah in Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah from Pirathon,
Hiddai from the Gaash ravines,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Abi Albon from Beth Arabah,
Azmaveth from Bahurim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elihba from Shaalbon,
Bene Jashen,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jonathan (son of Shammah the Hararite),
Ahiam (son of Sharar the Hararite),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eliphelet (son of Ahasbai and grandson of a man from Maacah),
Eliam (son of Ahithophel) from Gilo,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hezrai from Carmel,
Paarai from Arabah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Igal (son of Nathan) from Zobah,
Bani from the tribe of Gad,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Zelek from Ammon,
Naharai from Beeroth, armorbearer for Zeruiah’s son Joab,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ira (descendant of Ithra),
Gareb (descendant of Ithra),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Uriah the Hittite—
37 in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh became angry with Israel again, so he provoked David to turn against Israel. He said, “Go, count Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David said to Joab, the commander of the army who was with him, “Go throughout the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beersheba and count the people. That way I will know how many there are.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab responded to the king, “May Yahweh your Elohim multiply the people a hundred times over, and may Your Majesty live to see it. But why does Your Majesty wish to do this?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the king overruled Joab and the commanders of the army. So they left the king in order to count the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They crossed the Jordan River and camped at Aroer, south of the city in the middle of the valley. Then they went to Gad and to Jazer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to Gilead and to Tahtim Hodshi and then to Dan Jaan and around toward Sidon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to the fortified city of Tyre and all the cities of the Hivites and the Canaanites. Then they went to Beersheba in the Negev of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they had covered the whole country, they came to Jerusalem after 9 months and 20 days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab reported the census figures to the king: In Israel there were 800,000 able-bodied men who could serve in the army, and in Judah there were 500,000.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David counted the people, his conscience troubled him. David said to Yahweh, “I have committed a terrible sin by what I have done. Yahweh, please forgive me because I have acted very foolishly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David got up in the morning, Yahweh spoke his word to the prophet Gad, David’s seer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go and tell David, ‘This is what Yahweh says: I’m offering you three choices. Choose the one you want me to do to you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Gad came to David, he told David this and asked, “Should seven years of famine come to you and your land, or three months during which you flee from your enemies as they pursue you, or should there be a three-day plague in your land? Think it over, and decide what answer I should give the one who sent me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I’m in a desperate situation,” David told Gad. “Please let us fall into Yahweh’s hands because he is very merciful. But don’t let me fall into human hands.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh sent a plague among the Israelites from that morning until the time he had chosen. Of the people from Dan to Beersheba, 70,000 died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the Messenger stretched out his arm to destroy Jerusalem, Yahweh changed his mind about the disaster. “Enough!” he said to the Messenger who was destroying the people. “Put down your weapon.” The Messenger of Yahweh was at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When David saw the Messenger who had been killing the people, he said to Yahweh, “I’ve sinned. I’ve done wrong. What have these sheep done? Please let your punishment be against me and against my father’s family.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That day Gad came to David and said to him, “Go, set up an altar for Yahweh at Araunah the Jebusite’s threshing floor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David went as Gad had told him and as Yahweh had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Araunah looked down and saw the king and his men coming toward him, he went out and bowed down with his face touching the ground in front of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Why has Your Majesty come to me?” Araunah asked.
David answered, “To buy the threshing floor from you and to build an altar for Yahweh. Then the plague on the people will stop.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Araunah said to David, “Take it, Your Majesty, and offer whatever you think is right. There are oxen for the burnt offering, and there are threshers and oxen yokes for firewood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All this Araunah gave to the king and said, “May Yahweh your Elohim accept you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“No!” the king said to Araunah. “I must buy it from you at a fair price. I won’t offer Yahweh my Elohim burnt sacrifices that cost me nothing.”
So David bought the threshing floor and the oxen for 1¼ pounds of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David built an altar for Yahweh there and sacrificed burnt offerings and fellowship offerings. So Yahweh heard the prayers for the country, and the plague on Israel stopped.
verses.speaker: Narrator
